skill.name: context7-efficient
skill.description: Token-efficient library documentation fetcher using Context7 MCP with 86.8% token savings through intelligent shell pipeline filtering. Fetches code examples, API references, and best practices for JavaScript, Python, Go, Rust, and other libraries. Use when users ask about library documentation, need code examples, want API usage patterns, are learning a new framework, need syntax reference, or troubleshooting with library-specific information. Triggers include questions like "Show me React hooks", "How do I use Prisma", "What's the Next.js routing syntax", or any request for library/framework documentation.

security_audit.summary: Legitimate documentation fetcher with behavior matching stated purpose. Uses Context7 MCP service for library docs. Network calls limited to localhost MCP server. Shell scripts used for token-efficient filtering as designed.

low_findings.title: Subprocess with shell=True in mcp-client.py
low_findings.description: The StdioTransport class uses subprocess.Popen with shell=True (line 204-211) to spawn MCP servers via npx. While this is necessary for MCP server spawning and commands are controlled by library names, shell=True with user-controlled input carries inherent risk. Quote from code: `self._process = subprocess.Popen(self.command, shell=True, ...)`

content.value_statement: Library documentation requests consume significant context tokens. This skill reduces token usage by 77 percent through intelligent shell pipeline filtering. Developers get code examples and API references without context bloat.
actual_capabilities: Fetch documentation for JavaScript, Python, Go, Rust, and other libraries
Extract code examples with automatic language detection
Filter API signatures and function declarations
Identify important notes and warnings from documentation
Reduce token usage by 77 percent through shell pipeline processing
Support both code mode and info mode for different documentation types
limitations: Requires Context7 MCP server to be running
Only works with libraries available in Context7 database
Token savings depend on documentation structure and size
Filtered content may miss contextual explanations in info mode

faq.question: Which libraries are supported?
faq.answer: Context7 covers major libraries including React, Next.js, Express, Prisma, MongoDB, Vue, FastAPI, Django, and many others in JavaScript, Python, Go, and Rust ecosystems.

faq.question: What are the token savings?
faq.answer: Typical responses drop from 934 tokens to 205 tokens, achieving 77 percent reduction while preserving all code examples and API signatures.

faq.question: How does it integrate with Claude Code?
faq.answer: The shell pipeline runs in a subprocess, keeping full documentation out of Claude context. Only filtered content enters the LLM context through standard output.

faq.question: Is my data sent anywhere?
faq.answer: Documentation is fetched from the Context7 MCP service via local server. No user code or project data is transmitted outside the MCP protocol.

faq.question: Why is output truncated?
faq.answer: The filtering extracts only code blocks, API signatures, and key notes. Use page numbers or broader topics to get more content if needed.

faq.question: How is this different from direct MCP calls?
faq.answer: Direct MCP calls return full documentation text. This skill applies shell filters (awk, grep, sed) to extract only essentials, dramatically reducing token usage.
